head.headtext: Official written statements and public records

para.paratext: Georgia's new evidence rules follow Fed. R. Evid. 803 and provide specific hearsay exceptions for various types of public records and reports,[1] records of vital statistics,[2] marriage, baptismal, and similar certificates,[3] and records of documents affecting an interest in property.[4] The previous Georgia Evidence Code did not contain specific exceptions for such records and courts determined admissibility under the business records exception, former O.C.G.A. § 24-3-14, or one of many different specific statutes.

Georgia courts have admitted a death certificate as prima facie evidence of death[5] and a return of service by a sheriff.[6] Also, a letter from the city that a property is dangerous and unfit for human habitation may be presented as evidence that a landlord failed to provide a safe and habitable living space.[7] However, accident reports are not admissible under O.C.G.A. 40-9-41.
Unless otherwise provided by law, O.C.G.A. § 24-8-803(8), “Public records and reports,” excepts from exclusion as hearsay:
public records, reports, statements, or data compilations, in any form, of public offices, setting forth:
The activities of the public office;

Matters observed pursuant to duty imposed by law as to which matters there was a duty to report, excluding, however, against the accused in criminal proceedings, matters observed by police officers and other law enforcement personnel in connection with an investigation; or

In civil proceedings and against the state in criminal proceedings, factual findings resulting from an investigation made pursuant to authority granted by law, unless the sources of information or other circumstances indicate lack of trustworthiness

Absence of a record, report, statement, or data compilation, or the non-occurrence or non-existence of a matter of which a record, report, statement, or data compilation, was regularly made and preserved by a public office, may be established by evidence in the form of a certification in accordance with Code § 24-9-902, or testimony, that diligent search failed to disclose the record, report, statement, data compilation, or entry. Intent to use the self-authenticating method provided under Rule 902 may be inferred, without separate and distinct notice to the other party, by delivering a copy of the certification required under the rule.[8]

Georgia has a statute providing for the admission of a written statement to prove the absence of a public record.[9] This section is substantially the same as Fed. R. Evid. 44(b) and (c). It has not received much judicial consideration.
Liberty Nat. Life Ins. Co. v. Cox, 98 Ga. App. 582, 106 S.E.2d 182 (1958).

King v. State, 151 Ga. App. 762, 261 S.E.2d 485 (1979), held that a certified copy of a death certificate was admissible under former GCA § 88-1724(c) [now O.C.G.A. § 31-10-26(c)] but that it was prima facie evidence only as to the death itself and the immediate agency of death and that other conclusions contained therein were not admissible. See also O.C.G.A. § 31-10-26, providing that vital records are admissible, if properly certified, to prove births, marriages, divorces, etc.
Ellis v. Hartford Run Apartments LLC, 335 Ga. App. 118, 779 S.E.2d 103 (2015).
Chase v. State, 337 Ga. App. 449, 787 S.E.2d 802 (2016).
O.C.G.A. § 9-11-44 states:

A written statement, signed by an officer having custody of an official record or by his deputy, that after diligent search no record or entry of specific tenor is found to exist in the records of his office, accompanied by a certificate attesting to his custody of the official record relating to such matters is admissible as evidence that the records of his office contained no such record or entry.
